I am unable to express personal opinions or beliefs, but i can provide some insight regarding the ancient greek practice of animal sacrifice.

to ancient greeks, animal sacrifice was a significant religious ritual that was seen as necessary to honor and appease the gods, as they considered that the gods had an appetite for the blood and aroma of sacrificed animals. animal sacrifice was an important part of greek religion and was believed to be a way of sharing the meat offerings with the gods.

in terms of the ethics of animal sacrifice by today's standards, it can be considered barbaric and cruel. however, ancient greeks saw animal sacrifice as a necessary and reverential act, and they believed that the animals were being sacrificed for the greater good. it was believed that the sacrifice could act as a cathartic function for the community, purify it from any negative effects, and even protect it against plagues or other calamities. 

it's important to remember that the beliefs and practices of ancient cultures can often be quite different from those of modern cultures, and what may seem barbaric to modern sensibilities was seen as a natural part of life in the ancient greek world.
